_name: Large Cycles in Graphs Around Conjectures of Bondy and Jung - Modifications and Sharpness

description.title: Large Cycles in Graphs Around Conjectures of Bondy and Jung - Modifications and Sharpness

equations.text: Theorem A is    c -sharp for each λ ≤ δ +1 2 , κ -sharp for each λ ≤ δ +1 2 , δ -sharp for each λ ≤ δ +1 2 .
Theorem 3 is    c -sharp for each λ ≥ δ +1 2 , κ -sharp for each λ ≥ δ +1 2 , δ -sharp for each λ ≥ δ +1 2 .
Theorem 1 is    c -sharp for each λ ≥ δ +1 2 , κ -sharp for each λ ≤ δ +1 2 , δ -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ .
Theorem 2 is    c -sharp for each λ ≤ δ +1 2 , κ -sharp for each λ ≥ δ +1 2 , δ -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ .
Theorem C is    c -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ , κ -sharp for each λ ≤ δ +1 2 , δ -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ .
Theorem D is    c -sharp for each λ ≤ δ +1 2 , κ -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ , δ -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ .
Theorem 5 is    c -sharp for each λ ≥ δ +1 2 , κ -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ , δ -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ .
Theorem 4 is    c -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ , κ -sharp for each λ ≥ δ +1 2 , δ -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ .
Theorem E is    c -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ , κ -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ , δ -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ .
Theorem B is    c -sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2 , κ -sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2 , c -sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2 .
Theorem 8 is    c -sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2 , κ -sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2 , c -sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2 .
Theorem 6 is    c -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ , κ -sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2 , c -sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2 .
Theorem 7 is    c -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ , κ -sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2 , c -sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2 .
Theorem F is    c -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ , κ -sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2 , c -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ .
Theorem G is    c -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ , κ -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ , c -sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2 .
Theorem 10 is    c -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ , κ -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ , c -sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2 .
Theorem 9 is    c -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ , κ -sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2 , c -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ .
Theorem H is    c -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ , κ -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ , c -sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ .

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: arXiv:2305.02332v1 [math.CO] 3 May 2023

main-text.name: title
main-text.text: Large Cycles in Graphs Around Conjectures of Bondy and Jung-Modifications and Sharpness

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Zhora Nikoghosyan

main-text.name: subtitle-level-1
main-text.text: Abstract

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: A number of new sufficient conditions for generalized cycles (large cycles including Hamilton and dominating cycles as special cases) in an arbitrary κ-connected graph (κ = 1, 2,...) and new lower bounds for the circumference (the length of a longest cycle) are derived, inspiring a number of modifications of famous conjectures of Bondy (1980) and Jung (2001). All results are shown to be best possible in a sense and cannot be derived directly from Bondy's and Jung's conjectures as special cases.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Keywords: Hamilton cycle, Dominating cycle, Longest cycle, Large cycle.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: MSC-class: 05C38 (primary), 05C45, 05C40 (secondary)

main-text.name: subtitle-level-1
main-text.text: 1 Introduction

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Only finite undirected graphs without loops or multiple edges are considered. Notation and terminology not defined here follow that in [3]. Let G = (V,E) be a graph with vertex set V (G) and edge set E (G). For a subset S ⊂ V (G), we denote by G-S the maximum subgraph of G with vertex set V (G)-S. For a subgraph H of G, we use G-H to denote G-V (H).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: We use δ and α to denote the minimum degree and the independence number of G, respectively. The minimum degree sum of any k independent vertices in a graph is denoted by σ k, if α ≥ k. If α < k, we set σ k = + ∞. For a special case, we have σ$_{1}$ = δ.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: By the standard definition, a sequence v$_{1}$v$_{2}$...v t v$_{1}$ of distinct vertices v$_{1}$,...,v t in G is called a simple cycle (or just a cycle) of order t (the number of vertices) if v i v i +1 ∈ E (G) for each i ∈ { 1,...,t }, where v t +1 = v$_{1}$. In particular, for t = 1, the cycle v$_{1}$ coincides with the vertex v$_{1}$. So, each vertex and edge in a graph can be considered as a cycle of orders 1 and 2, respectively.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: A cycle in a graph G is called a Hamilton cycle of G if it contains all the vertices of G. A graph G is called hamiltonian if G contains a Hamilton cycle.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: A cycle Q of a graph G is called dominating cycle if every edge of G is incident with at least one vertex of Q.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: In 1980, Bondy [4] introduced the first type of generalized cycles, including Hamilton and dominating cycles as special cases: for a positive integer λ, we call Q a D λ-cycle if | H | ≤ λ-1 for every component H of G-Q. In other words, Q is a D λ-cycle of G if and only if every connected subgraph of order λ of G has at least one vertex with Q in common. In fact, a D λ-cycle dominates all connected subgraphs of order λ. According to this definition, Q is a Hamilton cycle if and only if Q is a D$_{1}$-cycle; and Q is a dominating cycle if and only if Q is a D$_{2}$-cycle.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: In this paper, we consider another two types of generalized cycles including Hamilton and dominating cycles as special cases. For a positive integer λ, a cycle Q is called a PD λ-cycle (PD-Path Dominating) if each path of order at least λ in G has at least one vertex with Q in common. Next, we call a cycle Q a CD λ-cycle (CD-Cycle Dominating; introduced in [13]) if each cycle of order at least λ has at least one vertex with Q in common. Actually, a PD λ-cycle dominates all paths of order λ in G; and a CD λ-cycle dominates all cycles of order λ in G. In terms of PD λ and CD λ-cycles, Q is a Hamilton cycle if and only if either Q is a PD$_{1}$-cycle or a CD$_{1}$-cycle. Further, Q is a dominating cycle if and only if either Q is a PD$_{2}$-cycle or a CD$_{2}$-cycle.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Throughout the paper, we consider a graph G on n vertices with minimum degree δ and connectivity κ. Further, let C be a longest cycle in G with c = | C |, and let p and c denote the orders of a longest path and

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: a longest cycle in G-C, respectively. In terms of p and c, C is a Hamilton cycle if and only if either p ≤ 0 or c ≤ 0. Similarly, C is a dominating cycle if and only if p ≤ 1 or c ≤ 1.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: In 1980, Bondy [4] conjectured a common generalization of some well-known degree-sum conditions for P D λ-cycles (called (σ, p)-version) including Hamilton cycles (P D$_{1}$-cycles) and dominating cycles (P D$_{2}$ cycles) as special cases.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Conjecture A (Bondy [4],1980): (σ, p)-version

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Let C be a longest cycle in a λ-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G of order n. If σ λ +1 ≥ n + λ (λ-1), then p ≤ λ-1.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Parts of Conjecture A were proved by Ore [16] (λ = 1), Bondy [4] (λ = 2) and Zou [18] (λ = 3). For the general case, Conjecture A is still open.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: The long cycles analogue (so called reverse version) of Bondys conjecture (Conjecture A) can be formulated as follows.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Conjecture B : (reverse, σ, p)-version

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Let C be a longest cycle in a λ-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G. If p ≥ λ-1, then c ≥ σ λ-λ (λ-2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Parts of Conjecture B were proved by Dirac [6] (λ = 1), Bondy [2], Bermond [1], Linial [11] (λ = 2), Fraisse, Yung [8] (λ = 3) and Chiba, Tsugaki, Yamashita [5] (λ = 4).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: The initial motivations of Conjecture A and Conjecture B come from their minimal degree versions-the most popular and much studied versions, which also remain unsolved.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Conjecture C (Bondy [4],1980): (δ, p)-version

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Let C be a longest cycle in a λ-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G of order n. If δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2, then p ≤ λ-1.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Parts of Conjecture C were proved by Dirac [6] (λ = 1), Nash-Williams [12] (λ = 2) and Fan [7] (λ = 3).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Conjecture D : (Jung [10], 2001): (reverse, δ, p)-version Let C be a longest cycle in a λ-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G. If p ≥ λ-1, then c ≥ λ (δ-λ + 2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Parts of Conjecture D were proved by Dirac [6] (λ = 1), Dirac [6] (λ = 2), Voss, Zuluaga [17] (λ = 3) and Jung [9] (λ = 4).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Note that CD λ-cycles are more suitable for research than P D λ-cycles since cycles in G-C are more symmetrical than paths in view of the connections between G-C and CD λ-cycles. This is the main reason why some minimum degree versions of Conjectures C and D have been solved just for CD λ-cycles.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: According to above arguments, it is natural to consider the exact analogues of Bondy's generalized conjecture (Conjecture A) and its reverse version (Conjecture B) for CD λ-cycles which we call (σ, c) and (reverse, σ, c)-versions, respectively.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Conjecture E : (σ, c)-version Let C be a longest cycle in a λ-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G of order n. If σ λ +1 ≥ n + λ (λ-1), then c ≤ λ-1.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Conjecture F : (reverse, σ, c)-version Let C be a longest cycle in a λ-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph. If c ≥ λ-1, then c ≥ σ λ-λ (λ-2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: In 2009, the author proved [14] the validity of minimum degree versions of Conjectures E and F.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem A ([14], 2009): (δ, c)-version Let C be a longest cycle in a λ-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G of order n. If δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2, then c ≤ λ-1.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem B ([14], 2009): (reverse, δ, c)-version Let C be a longest cycle in a λ-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph. If c ≥ λ-1, then c ≥ λ (δ-λ + 2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Actually, in [14] it was proved a significantly stronger result than Theorem A by showing that the conclusion c ≤ λ-1 in Theorem A can be strengthened to c ≤ min { λ-1, δ-λ }, called c-improvement.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem C ([14], 2009): (δ, c)-version, c-improvement Let C be a longest cycle in a λ-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G of order n. If δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2, then c ≤ min { λ-1, δ-λ }.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Recently, further improvements of Theorems A and C are presented [15] inspiring new conjectures in forms of improvements of initial generalized conjecture of Bondy.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem D ([15], 2022): (δ, c)-version, κ-improvement Let C be a longest cycle in a graph G of order n and λ a positive integer with 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ. If κ ≥ min { λ, δ-λ + 1 } and δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2, then c ≤ λ-1.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem E ([15], 2022): (δ, c)-version, (c, κ)-improvement Let C be a longest cycle in a graph G of order n and λ a positive integer with 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ. If κ ≥ min { λ, δ-λ + 1 } and δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2, then c ≤ min { λ-1, δ-λ }.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Analogously, the condition c ≥ λ-1 in Theorem B was weakened [14] to c ≥ min { λ-1, δ-λ + 1 }.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem F ([14], 2009): (reverse, δ, c)-version, c-improvement Let C be a longest cycle in a λ-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G. If c ≥ min { λ-1, δ-λ + 1 }, then c ≥ λ (δ-λ + 2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Furthermore, it was proved [15] that the connectivity condition κ ≥ λ in Theorem B can be weakened to κ ≥ min { λ, δ-λ + 2 }.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem G ([15], 2022): (reverse, δ, c)-version, κ-improvement Let C be a longest cycle in a graph G and λ a positive integer with 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ. If κ ≥ min { λ, δ-λ + 2 } and c ≥ λ-1, then c ≥ λ (δ-λ + 2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Finally, it was proved [15] that the connectivity condition κ ≥ λ in Theorem F can be weakened to κ ≥ min { λ, δ-λ + 2 }.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem H ([15], 2022): (reverse, δ, c)-version, (c, κ)-improvement Let C be a longest cycle in a graph G and λ a positive integer with 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ. If κ ≥ min { λ, δ-λ + 2 } and c ≥ min { λ-1, δ-λ + 1 }, then c ≥ λ (δ-λ + 2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: In this paper we present a number of new sufficient conditions for large cycles and new lower bounds for the circumference around conjectures of Bondy and Jung which cannot be derived directly from these conjectures as special cases. They can be characterized as modifications around conjectures of Bondy and Jung. Each of these modifications is shown to be best possible in a sense. Consider Theorem A to determine some kinds of sharpness. We say that Theorem A is c-sharp if the conclusion c ≤ λ-1 in Theorem A cannot be strengthened to c ≤ λ-2, that is, the upper bound λ-1 is available. Further, Theorem A is δ-sharp if the minimum degree condition δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2 cannot be weakened to δ ≥ n +1 λ +1 + λ-2. Finally, Theorem A is κ-sharp if the connectivity condition κ ≥ λ cannot be weakened to κ ≥ λ-1. The c-sharpness, κ-sharpness and c-sharpness for long cycle versions (reverse versions), say for theorem B, can be defined analogously.

main-text.name: subtitle-level-1
main-text.text: 2 Modifications

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: The first modification can be obtained from Theorem A by replacing the conclusion c ≤ λ-1 with c ≤ δ-λ, called c-modification.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem 1 : (δ, c)-version, c-modification Let C be a longest cycle in a λ-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G of order n. If δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2, then c ≤ δ-λ.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: The next modification can be obtained by replacing the connectivity condition κ ≥ λ in Theorem A with κ ≥ δ-λ + 1, called κ-modification.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem 2 : (δ, c)-version, κ-modification

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Let C be a longest cycle in a (δ-λ + 1)-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G of order n. If δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2, then c ≤ λ-1.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Another modification can be obtained by replacing the conclusion c ≤ λ-1 in Theorem 2 with c ≤ δ-λ, we obtain a new modification, called (c, κ)-modification.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem 3 : (δ, c)-version, (c, κ)-modification Let C be a longest cycle in a (δ-λ + 1)-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G of order n. If δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2, then c ≤ δ-λ.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Further, Theorem 2 can be improved by strengthening the conclusion c ≤ λ-1 to c ≤ min { λ-1, δ-λ }, called κ-modification with c-improvement.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem 4 : (δ, c)-version, κ-modification, c-improvement Let C be a longest cycle in a (δ-λ + 1)-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G of order n. If δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2, then c ≤ min { λ-1, δ-λ }.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Finally, Theorem 3 can be improved by relaxing the connectivity condition κ ≥ δ-λ + 1 to κ ≥ min { λ, δ-λ + 1 }, called c-modification with κ-improvement.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem 5 : (δ, c)-version, c-modification, κ-improvement Let C be a longest cycle in a graph G of order n and λ a positive integer with 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ. If κ ≥ min { λ, δ-λ + 1 } and δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2, then c ≤ δ-λ.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: The reverse versions of Theorems 1-5 are generated from Theorem B using different combinations of conditions κ ≥ λ, κ ≥ δ-λ + 2, κ ≥ min { λ, δ-λ + 2 } and c ≥ λ-1, c ≥ δ-λ + 1, c ≥ min { λ-1, δ-λ + 1 }. The first result can be considered as c-modification of Theorem B.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem 6 : (reverse, δ, c)-version, c-modification Let C be a longest cycle in a λ-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph. If c ≥ δ-λ + 1, then c ≥ λ (δ-λ + 2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: The κ-modification of Theorem B can be formulated as follows.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem 7 : (reverse, δ, c)-version, κ-modification Let C be a longest cycle in a (δ-λ + 2)-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph. If c ≥ λ-1, then c ≥ λ (δ-λ + 2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem B after c-modification and κ-modification, can be formulated as follows.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem 8 : (reverse, δ, c)-version, (c, κ)-modification Let C be a longest cycle in a (δ-λ + 2)-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph. If c ≥ δ-λ + 1, then c ≥ λ (δ-λ + 2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: The next result can be obtained from Theorem 8 by c-improvement.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem 9 : (reverse, δ, c)-version, κ-modification, c-improvement Let C be a longest cycle in a (δ-λ + 2)-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph. If c ≥ min { λ-1, δ-λ + 1 }, then c ≥ λ (δ-λ + 2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Finally, κ-improvement of Theorem 8 implies the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem 10 : (reverse, δ, c)-version, κ-improvement, c-modification Let C be a longest cycle in a graph G and λ a positive integer with 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ. If κ ≥ min { λ, δ-λ + 2 } and c ≥ δ-λ + 1, then c ≥ λ (δ-λ + 2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Observe that none of theorems 1-10 follows from Conjectures of Bondy and Jung as a special case.

main-text.name: subtitle-level-1
main-text.text: 3 Generalized modifications

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: In this section, motivated by Theorems 1-10 (minimum degree versions), we propose their generalized versions in terms of degree sums ((σ, c)-versions) as generalized modifications around Conjectures of Bondy and Jung. The first conjecture is a (σ, c)-generalization of Theorem 1.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Conjecture 1 : (σ, c)-version, c-modification Let C be a longest cycle in a λ-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G of order n. If σ λ +1 ≥ n + λ (λ-1), then c ≤ δ-λ.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: The (σ, c)-version of Theorem 2 can be formulated as follows.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Conjecture 2 : (σ, c)-version, κ-modification Let C be a longest cycle in a (δ-λ + 1)-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G of order n. If σ λ +1 ≥ n + λ (λ-1), then c ≤ λ-1.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: After (σ, c)-generalization, Theorem 3 implies the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Conjecture 3 : (σ, c)-version, κ-modification, c-modification Let C be a longest cycle in a (δ-λ + 1)-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G of order n. If σ λ +1 ≥ n + λ (λ-1), then c ≤ δ-λ.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Theorem 4, after (σ, c)-generalization, implies the following,

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Conjecture 4 : (σ, c)-version, κ-modification, c-improvement Let C be a longest cycle in a (δ-λ + 1)-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G of order n. If σ λ +1 ≥ n + λ (λ-1), then c ≤ min { λ-1, δ-λ }.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Finally, Theorem 5 implies the next conjecture after (σ, c)-generalization.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Conjecture 5 : (σ, c)-version, c-modification, κ-improvement Let C be a longest cycle in a min { λ, δ-λ +1 }-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph G of order n. If σ λ +1 ≥ n + λ (λ-1), then c ≤ δ-λ.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: The next five conjectures can be proposed by replacing the conclusion c ≥ λ (δ-λ + 2) in Theorems 6-10 with c ≥ σ λ-λ (λ-2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Conjecture 6 : (reverse, σ, c)-version, c-modification Let C be a longest cycle in a λ-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph. If c ≥ δ-λ + 1, then c ≥ σ λ-λ (λ-2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Conjecture 7 : (reverse, σ, c)-version, κ-modification Let C be a longest cycle in a (δ-λ + 2)-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph. If c ≥ λ-1, then c ≥ σ λ-λ (λ-2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Conjecture 8 : (reverse, σ, c)-version, κ-modification, c-modification Let C be a longest cycle in a (δ-λ +2)-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph. If c ≥ δ-λ +1, then c ≥ σ λ-λ (λ-2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Conjecture 9 : (reverse, δ, c)-version, κ-modification, c-improvement Let C be a longest cycle in a (δ-λ + 2)-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph. If c ≥ min { λ-1, δ-λ + 1 }, then c ≥ σ λ-λ (λ-2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Conjecture 10 : (reverse, δ, c)-version, c-modification, κ-improvement Let C be a longest cycle in a min { λ, δ-λ + 2 }-connected (1 ≤ λ ≤ δ) graph. If c ≥ δ-λ + 1, then c ≥ σ λ-λ (λ-2).

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: The (σ, p)-versions of Conjectures 1-10 can be proposed by a similar way.

main-text.name: subtitle-level-1
main-text.text: 4 Proofs

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: The proofs are based on several implications with the following two schemes:

main-text.name: subtitle-level-1
main-text.text: 5 On sharpness

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: To show the c, c, κ, δ-sharpness of all modifications (Theorems 1-10), we need analogous observations around original Theorems A, B and for all improvements-Theorems C, D, E, F, G and H.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: For Theorem A, take δ-λ + 3 disjoint copies of the complete graph K λ$_{-}$ 1 and join each vertex in their union to every vertex of a disjoint complete graph K δ$_{-}$λ +2, denoted by G = (δ-λ + 3) K λ$_{-}$ 1 + K δ$_{-}$λ +2. Then δ (G) = δ, c (G) = λ-1 and n (G) = λ (δ-λ + 3)-1. The connectivity condition κ (G) = δ-λ + 2 ≥ λ holds whenever λ ≤ δ +2 2. Further, the minimum degree condition δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2 is guaranteed whenever λ ≤ δ +1 2. So, Theorem A is c-sharp for each λ ≤ δ +1 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Now consider the κ-sharpness of Theorem A. Let G = λK δ$_{-}$λ +2 + K λ$_{-}$ 1. Then δ (G) = δ, κ (G) = λ-1 and n (G) = λ (δ-λ +3)-1. If λ ≤ δ +1 2, then it is easy to check that c (G) = δ-λ +2 ≥ λ and δ ≥ n +2 λ $_{+1}$+ λ-2. This graph example shows that the connectivity condition κ ≥ λ cannot be relaxed to κ ≥ λ-1. So, Theorem A is κ-sharp for each λ ≤ δ +1 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: As for δ-sharpness of Theorem A, we consider the graph example G = (δ-λ + 2) K λ + K δ$_{-}$λ +1 with δ (G) = δ, c (G) = λ and n (G) = (λ + 1)(δ-λ + 2)-1. Then

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Since the connectivity condition κ (G) = δ-λ +1 ≥ λ holds for each λ ≤ δ +1 2, we conclude that Theorem A is δ-sharp for each λ ≤ δ +1 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Combining above observations, we obtain the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 1.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: For Theorem 3, assume first that G = (λ +2) K δ$_{-}$λ + K λ +1. Then δ (G) = δ and n (G) = (λ +2)(δ-λ +1)-1. It is easy to see that the connectivity condition κ (G) = λ + 1 ≥ δ-λ + 1 and the minimum degree condition δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2 are guaranteed whenever λ ≥ δ +1 2. Since c (G) = δ-λ, Theorem 3 is c-sharp for each λ ≥ δ +1 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Now let G = (δ-λ + 1) K λ +1 + K δ$_{-}$λ. We have δ (G) = δ and n (G) = (λ + 2)(δ-λ + 1)-1. The inequality c (G) = λ + 1 ≥ δ-λ + 1 and the minimum degree condition δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2 are guaranteed whenever λ ≥ δ +1 2. Observing that κ (G) = δ-λ, we conclude that Theorem 3 is κ-sharp for each λ ≥ δ +1 2. For δ-sharpness, we let G = (δ-λ + 2) K λ + K δ$_{-}$λ +1. Then δ (G) = δ, κ (G) = δ-λ + 1 and n (G) = (λ + 1)(δ-λ + 2)-1. Therefore,

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Since the inequality c (G) = λ ≥ δ-λ + 1 holds whenever λ ≥ δ +1 2, we conclude that Theorem 3 is δ-sharp for each λ ≥ δ +1 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Thus, we have the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the sharpness of Theorem 1. Let G = (λ + 2) K δ$_{-}$λ + K λ +1. Then δ (G) = δ, κ (G) = λ + 1 > λ and n (G) = (λ + 2)(δ-λ + 1)-1. It is easy to see that the minimum degree condition δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2 is guaranteed whenever λ ≥ δ +1 2. Since c (G) = δ-λ, Theorem 1 is c-sharp for each λ ≥ δ +1 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the κ-sharpness of Theorem 1. Let G = λK δ$_{-}$λ +2 + K λ$_{-}$ 1. Then δ (G) = δ, κ (G) = λ-1, c (G) = δ-λ + 2 > δ-λ + 1 and n (G) = λ (δ-λ + 3)-1. If λ ≤ δ +1 2, then it is easy to check that δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2. This graph example shows that the connectivity condition κ ≥ λ cannot be relaxed to κ ≥ λ-1. So, Theorem 1 is κ-sharp for each λ ≤ δ +1 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Let G = (λ +1) K δ$_{-}$λ +1 + K λ. Then δ (G) = δ, c (G) = δ-λ +1, κ (G) = λ and n (G) = (λ +1)(δ-λ +2)-1. Observing also that

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: we conclude that Theorem 1 is δ-sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Thus, we have the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 3.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: For Theorem 2, take G = (δ-λ + 3) K λ$_{-}$ 1 + K δ$_{-}$λ +2. Then δ (G) = δ, n (G) = λ (δ-λ + 3)-1 and κ (G) = δ-λ + 2 > δ-λ + 1. The minimum degree condition δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2 is guaranteed whenever λ ≤ δ +1 2. Recalling that c (G) = λ-1, we conclude that Theorem 2 is c-sharp for each λ ≤ δ +1 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: For κ-sharpness, let G = (δ-λ + 1) K λ +1 + K δ$_{-}$λ. Then δ (G) = δ, c (G) = λ + 1 > λ and n (G) = (λ + 2)(δ-λ + 1)-1. The minimum degree condition δ ≥ n +2 λ +1 + λ-2 is guaranteed whenever λ ≥ δ +1 2. Observing also that κ (G) = δ-λ, we conclude that Theorem 2 is κ-sharp for each λ ≥ δ +1 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: For δ-sharpness, let G = (δ-λ + 2) K λ + K δ$_{-}$λ +1. Then δ (G) = δ, κ (G) = δ-λ + 1, c (G) = λ and n (G) = (λ + 1)(δ-λ + 2)-1. Therefore,

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Hence, Theorem 2 is δ-sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ. Thus, we have the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 4.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the sharpness of Theorem C. If λ ≤ δ +1 2, then we have Theorem A. By Proposition 1, Theorem C is (c, κ, δ)-sharp. If λ ≥ δ +1 2, then we have Theorem 1. By Proposition 3, Theorem C is (c, δ)-sharp. So, we have the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 5.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the sharpness of Theorem D. If λ ≤ δ +1 2, then we have Theorem A. By Proposition 1, Theorem D is (c, κ, δ)-sharp. If λ ≥ δ +1 2, then we have Theorem 2. By Proposition 4, Theorem D is (κ, δ)-sharp. So, we have the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 6.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the sharpness of Theorem 5. If λ ≤ δ +1 2, then we have Theorem 1. By Proposition 3, Theorem 5 is (κ, δ)-sharp. If λ ≥ δ +1 2, then we have Theorem 3. By Proposition 2, Theorem 5 is (c, κ, δ)-sharp. So, we have the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 7.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the sharpness of Theorem 4. If λ ≤ δ +1 2, then we have Theorem 2. By Proposition 4, Theorem 4 is (c, δ)-sharp. If λ ≥ δ +1 2, then we have Theorem 3. By Proposition 2, Theorem 4 is (c, κ, δ)-sharp. So, we have the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 8.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the sharpness of Theorem E. If λ ≤ δ +1 2, then we have Theorem A. By Proposition 1, Theorem E is (c, κ, δ)-sharp. If λ ≥ δ +1 2, then we have Theorem 3. By Proposition 2, Theorem E is (c, κ, δ)-sharp as well. So, we have the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 9.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Now we turn to the sharpness observations around Jung's conjecture.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the sharpness of Theorem B. Let G = (δ-λ + 3) K λ$_{-}$ 1 + K δ$_{-}$λ +2. Then δ (G) = δ and c (G) = λ-1. The connectivity condition κ (G) = δ-λ + 2 ≥ λ holds whenever λ ≤ δ +2 2. Observing also that c (G) = λ (δ-λ + 2), we conclude that Theorem B is c-sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: κ-sharpness of Theorem B. Let

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: G

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Then

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: δ (G) =

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: δ

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: and

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: c (G) =

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: (λ-1)(δ-λ + 3). The inequalities c (G) = δ-λ + 2 ≥ λ-1 and c (G) < λ (δ-λ + 2) are satisfied whenever λ ≤ δ +2 2. Observing also that κ (G) = λ-1, we conclude that Theorem B is κ-sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2. Consider the c sharpness of Theorem B. Let (δ-λ + 4) K λ$_{-}$ 2 + K δ$_{-}$λ +3. Then δ (G) = δ and c (G) = (λ-1)(δ-λ + 3). The connectivity condition κ (G) = δ-λ + 3 ≥ λ and the inequality c (G) < λ (δ-λ + 2) are satisfied whenever λ ≤ δ +2 2. Recalling also that c (G) = λ-2, we conclude that Theorem B is c-sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Combining these observations, we have the following.

main-text.name: subtitle-level-1
main-text.text: Proposition 10.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the sharpness of Theorem 8. Let G = (δ-λ +3) K λ$_{-}$ 1 + K δ$_{-}$λ +2 with δ (G) = δ, κ (G) = δ-λ +2 and c (G) = λ-1. The inequality c (G) = λ-1 ≥ δ-λ + 1 holds whenever λ ≥ δ +2 2. Observing also that c (G) = λ (δ-λ + 2), we conclude that Theorem 8 is c-sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the κ-sharpness of Theorem 8. Let G = (δ-λ + 2) K λ + K δ$_{-}$λ +1. Then δ (G) = δ, c (G) = (λ + 1)(δ-λ + 1). The inequalities c (G) = λ ≥ δ-λ + 1 and c (G) < λ (δ-λ + 2) are satisfied whenever λ ≥ δ +2 2. Since κ (G) = δ-λ + 1, Theorem 8 is κ-sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the c-sharpness of Theorem 8. Let G = (λ + 2) K δ$_{-}$λ + K λ +1 with δ (G) = δ and c (G) = (λ + 1)(δ-λ + 1). The inequalities κ (G) = λ + 1 ≥ δ-λ + 2 and c (G) < λ (δ-λ + 2) are satisfied whenever λ ≥ δ +2 2. Observing also that c (G) = δ-λ, we conclude that Theorem 8 is c-sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2. Combining these observations, we have the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 11.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the sharpness of Theorem 6. Let G = (λ + 1) K δ$_{-}$λ +1 + K λ. Then δ (G) = δ, c (G) = δ-λ + 1 and κ (G) = λ. Since c (G) = λ (δ-λ + 2), Theorem 6 is c-sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the κ-sharpness of Theorem 6. Let G = λK δ$_{-}$λ +2 + K λ$_{-}$ 1. Then δ (G) = δ, c (G) = δ-λ + 2 > δ-λ + 1 and c (G) = (λ-1)(δ-λ + 3). The inequality c (G) < λ (δ-λ + 2) is satisfied whenever λ ≤ δ +2 2. Since κ (G) = λ-1, Theorem B is κ-sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Let G = (λ + 2) K δ$_{-}$λ + K λ +1 with δ (G) = δ, κ (G) = λ + 1 > λ and c (G) = (λ + 1)(δ-λ + 1). The inequality c (G) < λ (δ-λ + 2) is satisfied whenever λ ≥ δ +2 2. Since c (G) = δ-λ, Theorem 8 is c-sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Combining these observations, we have the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 12.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the sharpness of Theorem 7. Let G = (δ-λ + 3) K λ$_{-}$ 1 + K δ$_{-}$λ +2. Then δ (G) = δ, c (G) = λ-1 and κ (G) = δ-λ + 2. Since c (G) = λ (δ-λ + 2), Theorem 7 is c-sharp for each 1 ≤ λ ≤ δ.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Let G = (δ-λ + 2) K λ + K δ$_{-}$λ +1 with δ (G) = δ, c (G) = λ > λ-1 and c (G) = (λ + 1)(δ-λ + 1). The inequality c (G) < λ (δ-λ + 2) holds whenever λ ≥ δ +2 2. Since κ (G) = δ-λ + 1, Theorem 7 is κ-sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Let (δ-λ +4) K λ$_{-}$ 2 + K δ$_{-}$λ +3. Then δ (G) = δ, κ (G) = δ-λ +3 > δ-λ +2 and c (G) = (λ-1)(δ-λ +3). The inequality c (G) < λ (δ-λ + 2) is satisfied whenever λ ≤ δ +2 2. Since c = λ-2, Theorem 7 is c-sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Combining these observations, we have the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 13.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the sharpness of Theorem F. If λ ≤ δ +2 2, then we have Theorem B. By Proposition 10, Theorem F is (c, κ, c)-sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2. If λ ≥ δ +2 2, then we have Theorem 6. By Proposition 12, Theorem F

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: is (c, c)-sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2. Combining these observations, we obtain the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 14.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the sharpness of Theorem G. If λ ≤ δ +2 2, then we have Theorem B. By Proposition 10, Theorem G is (c, κ, c)-sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2. If λ ≥ δ +2 2, then we have Theorem 7. By Proposition 13, Theorem G is (c, κ)-sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2. Combining these observations, we obtain the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 15.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the sharpness of Theorem 10. If λ ≤ δ +2 2, then we have Theorem 6. By Proposition 12, Theorem 10 is (c, κ)-sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2. If λ ≥ δ +2 2, then we have Theorem 8. By Proposition 11, Theorem 10 is (c, κ, c)-sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2. Combining these observations, we obtain the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 16.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the sharpness of Theorem 9. If λ ≤ δ +2 2, then we have Theorem 7. By Proposition 13, Theorem 9 is (c, c)-sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2. If λ ≥ δ +2 2, then we have Theorem 8. By Proposition 11, Theorem 9 is (c, κ, c)-sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2. Combining these observations, we obtain the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 17.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Consider the sharpness of Theorem H. If λ ≤ δ +2 2, then we have Theorem B. By Proposition 10, Theorem H is (c, κ, c)-sharp for each λ ≤ δ +2 2. If λ ≥ δ +2 2, then we have Theorem 8. By Proposition 11, Theorem H is (c, κ, c)-sharp for each λ ≥ δ +2 2. Combining these observations, we obtain the following.

main-text.name: text
main-text.text: Proposition 18.
